conclusion: To find the charge Q carried by the capacitor after the circuit stabilizes, we need to follow these steps.
Determine the equivalent resistance of the circuit.
Resistors R2 and R3 are in parallel, so 1/R23 = 1/R2 + 1/R3.
Substituting the given values, 1/R23 = 1/3Ω + 1/6Ω = 1/2Ω, therefore R23 = 2Ω.
R23 is in series with R1, so Req = R1 + R23 = 2Ω + 2Ω = 4Ω.
Calculate the total current through the circuit.
Using Ohm's law, the total current I from the battery is I = E/(Req + r) = 6V/(4Ω + 2Ω) = 1A.
Determine the voltage across the parallel combination R2 and R3.
The voltage drop across Req is VReq = I × Req = 1A × 4Ω = 4V.
Since R2 and R3 are in parallel, the voltage across both R2 and R3 is the same as the voltage across R23, which is 4V.
Calculate the charge on the capacitor.
The capacitor C is connected across R2 and R3. When the circuit stabilizes, the voltage across the capacitor will be equal to the voltage across R2 and R3, which is 4V.
The charge Q on the capacitor is given by Q = C × VR2 = 10μF × 4V = 40μC.
